choices.text: They are formed exclusively in the hepatic mitochondria
Ketone bodies are formed under conditions causing a high rate of fatty acid oxidation
Acetone is excreted via the lungs
Ketones are abundantly utilised in the liver

questions.text: All the following about ketone bodies are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Under metabolic conditions associated with high fatty acid oxidation, an excess of Acetyl-CoA is produced, saturating the Krebs cycle and preventing entry into gluconeogenesis. This leads to diversion of Acetyl-CoA for ketone body synthesis.
  • Ketone bodies are synthesised predominantly in the hepatic mitochondria from acetyl-CoA derived from β-oxidation of fatty acids. (Option A)
  • They are produced during fasting, prolonged exercise, or uncontrolled diabetes. (Option B)
  • Acetone, a minor ketone body, is volatile and is excreted via the lungs. (Option C)
  • Although the liver synthesises ketone bodies, it cannot utilise them because it lacks succinyl-CoA: acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase) required for ketone body utilisation. Hence, Option D is false.

questions.text: HMG CoA is utilised in all of the following reactions except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HMG-CoA is not involved in arginine metabolism.

HMG-CoA (3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA) is an important intermediate in several metabolic pathways:

  • Ketogenesis: Formation of HMG-CoA from three molecules of acetyl-CoA by the enzyme HMG-CoA synthase, which is the rate-limiting step of ketone body synthesis. (Option A ruled out)
  • Cholesterol synthesis: HMG-CoA is converted to mevalonate by HMG-CoA reductase, which is the rate-limiting step of cholesterol synthesis. (Option B ruled out)
  • Leucine metabolism: HMG-CoA acts as an intermediate in leucine catabolism. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Ketone bodies are utilised in all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ketone bodies are not utilised in the liver and the RBCs.
  • This is because the RBCs lack mitochondria and therefore cannot utilise ketone bodies and
  • The liver lacks the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl CoA acetoacetate CoA transferase) and therefore cannot utilise ketone bodies.

Explanation of other options:

Kidney and brain (Option B) can utilise ketone bodies, especially during prolonged fasting or starvation.

Kidney and heart (Option C) actively utilise ketone bodies as an energy source.

Muscle and brain (Option D) can both use ketone bodies, particularly when glucose availability is low.

questions.text:
All are true about ketosis and its tests except?
A. Rothera's test is answered by acetoacetate and acetone
B. Beta-hydroxybutyrate is the major ketone body in ketosis
C. Gerhardt's test is answered by Acetoacetate
D. In normal people, the ratio of BHB to Acetoacetate is 1:1
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A: Rothera's test: Saturate 5 ml of urine with solid ammonium sulfate. Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside, followed by 2 ml of liquor ammonia, along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta-hydroxybutyrate. Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.


B: Beta-hydroxybutyrate is produced from acetoacetate, which is the major ketone body in ketoacidosis.

C: Gerhardt's test for acetoacetic acid: To 5 ml of urine, add dilute ferric chloride solution drop by drop, till a maximum precipitate of ferric phosphate is obtained. This is to eliminate the phosphates, which may obscure the colour in the test. Filter. To the filtrate, add excess ferric chloride. A red colour indicates the presence of acetoacetic acid.

D: In normal individuals, the BHB to Acetoacetate ratio is approximately 1:1, but in ketosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis, this ratio shifts significantly, with beta-hydroxybutyrate predominating.

So, all statements are correct.

questions.text: The rate-limiting step of ketogenesis is the formation of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The formation of HMG CoA from acetoacetate and acetyl-CoA by the enzyme HMG CoA synthase is the rate-limiting step of ketogenesis.

Explanation of other options:

Thiolase (Option A): Thiolase catalyses a reversible reaction involved in the initial step of ketogenesis, but it is not rate-limiting.

HMG CoA reductase (Option C): HMG CoA reductase is not involved in ketone body synthesis. It plays a role in cholesterol synthesis in the cytoplasm, not the mitochondria.

Thiophorase (Option D): Thiophorase is involved in ketone body utilisation (breakdown) in extra-hepatic tissues and not in ketone body synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following does not stimulate ketogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An increase in the Insulin/Glucagon ratio will decrease ketogenesis by both decreasing the availability of FFA (by inhibition of hormone-sensitive lipase) and by inhibiting HMG CoA synthase in mitochondria.

The stimulation of ketogenesis takes place in three crucial ways. They include:

  • Increase in free fatty acid availability (Option A)
  • CPT-1 Gateway (Option B)
  • Decrease in insulin/glucagon ratio (Option D)

choices.text: Medium and short-chain fatty acid dehydrogenase

questions.text: A child in Jamaica presented with symptoms of fasting hypoglycemia, more severe at night, acute vomiting, which occurred 6 hours after ingestion of a fruit, and the child rapidly developed coma and died shortly after. Which is a possible step inhibited in the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Jamaican vomiting sickness is caused by eating the unripe fruit of the ackee tree, which contains the toxin
  • This inactivates medium and short-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, inhibiting oxidation and causing hypoglycemia.
  • Dicarboxylic aciduria is due to the excretion of C6-C10 dicarboxylic acid with nonketotic hypoglycemia due to the lack of medium and short-chain fatty acid dehydrogenase.
  • Recently, Jamaican vomiting sickness-like illness has been reported after consumption of large amounts of litchi by children from India, also, possibly by the same mechanism.

Explanation of other options:

Long-chain fatty acyl dehydrogenase (Option A): This enzyme is involved in long-chain fatty acid oxidation. In Jamaican vomiting sickness, it is specifically the medium and short-chain dehydrogenases that are inhibited.

HMG CoA synthase (Option C): HMG CoA synthase catalyses the rate-limiting step in ketogenesis, not directly related to the fatty acid oxidation block seen in this illness.

HMG CoA reductase (Option D): This enzyme is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis and is not related to fatty acid oxidation or ketogenesis in mitochondria.

choices.text: Zellweger syndrome is also called cerebrohepatorenal syndrome
Refsum's disease is a common disorder caused by phytanic acid accumulation
Zellweger syndrome is characterised by the absence of peroxisomes in the brain only

questions.text: True regarding peroxisomal disorders:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Zellweger syndrome, also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, is a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder caused by an inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues, not just the brain.
  • There is an accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in the brain tissue along with a generalised loss of peroxisomal function throughout the body.
  • The disease manifests with severe neurologic deficits and hepatic dysfunction, and most affected infants die within the first year of life.
  • Lorenzo's oil is used as a treatment for X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), not neonatal ALD. It is not related to Zellweger syndrome (Option A).
  • Refsum's disease is a rare peroxisomal disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase, leading to phytanic acid accumulation. It is not considered a common (Option C)
  • The absence of peroxisomes in Zellweger syndrome is systemic, affecting all tissues, not limited to the brain. (Option D)

questions.text: In which of the following pathways is the mitochondria not involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • De Novo Fatty Acid Synthesis (Lipogenesis) occurs in the cytosol, not in mitochondria.
  • The pathway was elucidated by Feodor Lynen, hence also referred to as Lynen's Spiral.
  • Major sites include: Liver, kidney, brain, lung, lactating mammary gland, and adipose tissue.
  • Mitochondria provide acetyl-CoA (as citrate), but the actual fatty acid synthesis takes place in the cytosol.
  • Cofactors required:
    • NADPH
    • ATP
    • Mn2+
    • Biotin
    • HCO3- (as a source of CO2)
  • Mitochondria are involved in:
    • DNA Synthesis (mitochondrial DNA replication) (Option B)
    • Fatty Acid Oxidation (beta-oxidation within mitochondria) (Option C)
    • Protein Synthesis (via mitochondrial ribosomes) (Option D)

questions.text: Triacylglycerol is a storage form of energy. The storage triacylglycerols are hydrolysed by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Triacylglycerol undergoes hydrolysis by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in adipose tissue to form free fatty acids (FFA) and glycerol.
  • This process provides energy during fasting and stress by mobilising fat stores.
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase is regulated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon (activators), and insulin (inhibitor).

Explanation of other options:

Pancreatic Lipase (Option A): This enzyme hydrolyses dietary triacylglycerols in the small intestine, not stored fat.

Lipoprotein Lipase (Option B): This enzyme hydrolyses triacylglycerols in circulating lipoproteins (chylomicrons, VLDL) to facilitate fat storage in tissues.

Lysosomal Lipase (Option C): This enzyme is involved in the hydrolysis of intracellular lipids within lysosomes, not in the mobilisation of stored triacylglycerol for energy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Fatty Acid Synthase Complex?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is not a part FAS Complex.

Fatty Acid Synthase (FAS) Multienzyme Complex

  • The complex is a homodimer of two identical polypeptide monomers, in which six enzyme activities and the acyl carrier protein (ACP).
  • Six enzyme activities of the Fatty Acid Synthase Complex are
    • Ketoacyl Synthase (Option D)
    • Malonyl-Acetyl Transacylase
    • Dehydratase
    • Enoyl Reductase (Option B)
    • Ketoacyl Reductase (Option A)
    • Thioesterase (Deacylase).

choices.text: Precursor for the synthesis of cholesterol and other steroids
Starting material for the synthesis of fatty acid

questions.text: True about acetyl-CoA:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fates of Acetyl-CoA:

  • Synthesis of Cholesterol and other steroids. (Option A)
  • Synthesis of Fatty Acid. (Option C)
  • Synthesis of Ketone Bodies. (Option B)
  • Enter into the TCA Cycle

questions.text: NADPH is required for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fatty acid synthesis is a reductive biosynthetic pathway that requires the following cofactors and conditions:

NADPH:

  • NADPH is the principal reducing equivalent required for the synthesis of fatty acids.
  • The biosynthesis of fatty acids requires NADPH as a reducing agent and occurs primarily in the cytosol of the liver and adipose tissue.
  • Sources:
    • Pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) (main source)
    • Malic enzyme converts malate to pyruvate while generating NADPH.

Other essential cofactors and substrates:

  • Acetyl-CoA: The two-carbon donor and fundamental building block.
  • ATP: Required for the activation of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA.
  • Biotin: Coenzyme for acetyl-CoA carboxylase, which catalyses the formation of malonyl-CoA.
  • HCO3- (Bicarbonate): Provides the carboxyl group for carboxylation of acetyl-CoA.
  • Mn2+: Serves as a cofactor for various enzymes in fatty acid synthesis, especially acetyl-CoA carboxylase.

Explanation of other options:

Gluconeogenesis (Option A): Uses NADH, not NADPH.

Glycolysis (Option B): Utilises NAD+ as a coenzyme in the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase step.

Glycogenolysis (Option D): Mainly involves glycogen phosphorylase and does not require NADPH.

questions.text: The first step in fatty acid synthesis involves:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acetyl-CoA Carboxylase (ACC):

  • Catalyses the first and rate-limiting step of fatty acid synthesis.
  • Reaction:

Acetyl-CoA (2C) + CO2 + ATP → Malonyl-CoA (3C) + ADP + Pi

  • Requires:
    • ATP
    • Biotin (Vitamin B7) as a prosthetic group (covalently bound coenzyme)
    • HCO3- (as the CO2 source)
  • ACC is a multifunctional enzyme, but it is not part of the fatty acid synthase (FAS) complex.

Fatty Acid Synthase (FAS):

  • A multienzyme protein complex that carries out the subsequent steps of fatty acid chain elongation.
  • Uses malonyl-CoA (from ACC) and NADPH for chain elongation.

Explanation of other options:

β-Hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase (Option B): Involved in fatty acid β-oxidation, not synthesis.

Acetyl dehydrogenase (Option C): No such enzyme

Pyruvate kinase (Option D): Involved in glycolysis, converting phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate.

choices.text: 2 in Ist cycle and 4 in the 2nd cycle
4 in Ist cycle and 2 in 2nd cycle
2 in Ist cycle and 2 in the 2nd cycle
4 in Ist cycle and 4 in the 2nd cycle

questions.text: Carbon atoms added in fatty acid synthesis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • First Cycle of Fatty Acid Synthase Complex: 2 C from Acetyl CoA condense with 3 Carbon atoms of Malonyl CoA, followed by liberating 1 CO2. Hence, 4 Carbon atoms are added.
  • In the second cycle, to the existing 4-carbon fatty acyl residue, 2 Carbon atoms are added by condensation with 3 Carbon atoms of Malonyl CoA, followed by liberating 1 CO2.

questions.text: In which organelle(s) of the hepatocyte, the elongation of long-chain fatty acids take place?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Elongation of long-chain fatty acids (typically ≥ C10) primarily occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of hepatocytes through the microsomal fatty acid elongation system.
  • This system adds two carbon units at a time to existing fatty acyl-CoA chains.
  • The elongation reaction uses malonyl-CoA as the carbon donor and NADPH as the reducing agent.
  • Both saturated and unsaturated fatty acids can be elongated in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
  • This process is fundamental in tissues like the brain, where longer-chain fatty acids (C22-C24) are needed for sphingolipid synthesis during myelination.

Explanation of other Options:

Golgi body (Option B): The Golgi apparatus is mainly involved in protein processing and glycosylation, not fatty acid elongation.

Lysosomes (Option C): Lysosomes are involved in the degradation of cellular waste, not biosynthetic processes like fatty acid elongation.

Ribosome (Option D): Ribosomes are responsible for protein synthesis, not lipid metabolism.

questions.text: Acetyl-CoA acts as a substrate for all the enzymes except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acetyl-CoA serves as a substrate for many enzymes involved in biosynthetic pathways, but not for malic enzyme.

  • Malic enzyme catalyses the oxidative decarboxylation of malate to pyruvate, producing NADPH and CO2.
  • It does not utilise Acetyl-CoA as a substrate.

In contrast:

  • HMG-CoA synthase uses Acetyl-CoA to form HMG-CoA (key step in ketogenesis and cholesterol synthesis). (Option A)
  • Malonyl-CoA synthetase activates Acetyl-CoA to form Malonyl-CoA (used in fatty acid synthesis). (Option C)
  • Fatty acid synthase (FAS) utilises acetyl-CoA and malonyl-CoA as building blocks for fatty acid chain elongation. (Option D)

questions.text: Acetyl-CoA Carboxylase is activated by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is an allosteric enzyme and is activated by citrate, which:
    • Increases in concentration in the well-fed state
    • It is an indicator of a plentiful supply of acetyl-CoA
    • Promotes conversion of the enzyme from an inactive dimer to an active polymeric form (molecular mass: several million)
  • Acetyl-CoA Carboxylase is the most important enzyme in the regulation of lipogenesis.

Inactivation is promoted by:

  • Phosphorylation of the enzyme
  • Long-chain acyl-CoA molecules (e.g., Palmitoyl CoA): negative feedback inhibition by a product of the reaction
  • Acyl-CoA also inhibits the mitochondrial tricarboxylate transporter, preventing citrate egress and enzyme activation.

Hormonal regulation:

  • Glucagon, epinephrine: inhibit via phosphorylation
  • Insulin: activates via dephosphorylation

Explanation of other options:

Malonyl-CoA (Option A): Malonyl-CoA is the product of the reaction catalysed by ACC, not its activator.

Palmitoyl-CoA (Option C): Palmitoyl-CoA is a long-chain fatty acyl-CoA that inhibits ACC by negative feedback.

Acetoacetate (Option D): Acetoacetate is a ketone body and does not play a role in the regulation of ACC.

questions.text: The subcellular site of the breakdown of long-chain fatty acids to acetyl-CoA via beta-oxidation is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The subcellular site of β-oxidation of long-chain fatty acids to acetyl-CoA is the mitochondrial matrix.

  • Carnitine-acyl carnitine translocase binds acyl carnitine and transports it across the inner mitochondrial membrane in exchange for carnitine.
  • The acyl group is then transferred to CoA to reform acyl-CoA, and carnitine is liberated.
  • This reaction is catalysed by carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II (CPT-II), which is located on the inner side of the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Thus, the β-oxidation spiral proceeds inside the mitochondrial matrix, where acyl-CoA is sequentially cleaved to form acetyl-CoA units.

Explanation of other options:

Cytosol (Option A) is the site of fatty acid synthesis, not β-oxidation.

Endoplasmic reticulum (Option C) is involved in fatty acid elongation and desaturation.

Mitochondrial intermembrane space (Option D) is involved in electron transport chain processes.

choices.text: 8 FADH2, 8 NADH and 8 acetyl-CoA molecules
8 FADH2, 8 NADH and 7 acetyl-CoA molecules
7 FADH2, 8 NADH and 8 acetyl-CoA molecules
7 FADH2, 7 NADH and 8 acetyl-CoA molecules

questions.text: The breakdown of one molecule of a C16 fully saturated fatty acid (palmitic acid) by β-oxidation leads to the formation of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The breakdown of palmitic acid (C16) requires 7 cycles of β-oxidation, each producing 1 FADH2 and 1 NADH molecule and results in the formation of eight 2C acetyl-CoA molecules.
  • Oxidation of Fatty Acids Produces a Large Quantity of ATP.
  • Transport of electrons from FADH2 and NADH via the respiratory chain leads to the synthesis of 4 high-energy phosphates for each of the seven cycles needed for the breakdown of the C16 fatty acid, palmitate, to acetyl-CoA (7 × 4 = 28).
  • A total of 8 mol of acetyl-CoA is formed, and each gives rise to 10 mol of ATP on oxidation in the citric acid cycle, making 8 × 10 = 80 mol. Two must be subtracted for the initial activation of the fatty acid, yielding a net gain of 106 mol of ATP per mole of palmitate.

questions.text: Number of ATP formed by oxidation of one molecule of palmitic acid (16 C):
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The oxidation of palmitic acid (C16) involves multiple cycles of β-oxidation, each producing FADH2, NADH, and acetyl-CoA, ultimately leading to ATP production.
  • The number of β-oxidation cycles = (n/2) - 1, where n = number of carbon atoms.
  • For palmitic acid (16C): (16/2) - 1 = 7 cycles.

Each cycle produces:

  • 1 FADH2 (7 total)
  • 1 NADH (7 total)
  • Each cycle cleaves 2C units as acetyl-CoA.
  • Total acetyl-CoA molecules = 8 (from 16 carbons).

ATP Yield:

  • From 7 FADH2 → 7 × 1.5 ATP = 5 ATP
  • From 7 NADH → 7 × 2.5 ATP = 5 ATP
  • From 8 acetyl-CoA (TCA cycle) → 8 × 10 ATP = 80 ATP

Total ATP before activation = 10.5 + 17.5 + 80 = 108 ATP

  • Subtract 2 ATP for activation of palmitate → Net ATP = 106 ATP

questions.text: Beta Oxidation in the Peroxisome generates:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Peroxisomes oxidise very long-chain fatty acids (e.g., C20, C22) through a modified form of β-oxidation.
  • This process results in the formation of acetyl-CoA and H2O2 (produced in the flavoprotein-linked dehydrogenase step), which is subsequently broken down by catalase.
  • Unlike mitochondrial β-oxidation, peroxisomal dehydrogenation is not linked to ATP generation via oxidative phosphorylation. Instead, this system prepares fatty acids for further oxidation in mitochondria by shortening them, typically ending at octanoyl-CoA.
  • Other functions of peroxisomes include:
    • Shortening of the cholesterol side chain in bile acid formation
    • Synthesis of ether glycerolipids, cholesterol, and dolichol
    • Peroxisomal β-oxidation enzymes are induced by high-fat diets and, in some species, by hypolipidemic drugs such as clofibrate.

Explanation of other options:

NADPH (Option A) is not produced in peroxisomal β-oxidation.

Long-chain fatty acids (Option C) are the substrates, not products, of peroxisomal oxidation.

FADH2 (Option D): Unlike mitochondrial β-oxidation, peroxisomal dehydrogenation does not yield FADH2.

choices.text: Its formation from acetyl-CoA and bicarbonate by the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the main rate-limiting step in fatty acid synthesis.
It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I.
It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II.
It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitineacylcarnitine translocase.

questions.text: Malonyl CoA, the first intermediate in fatty acid synthesis, is an important regulator of fatty acid metabolism because:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Malonyl CoA, the first intermediate in fatty acid synthesis, plays a crucial regulatory role in fatty acid metabolism.
  • Its formation from acetyl-CoA and bicarbonate by the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase represents the rate-limiting step in lipogenesis.
  • Importantly, malonyl-CoA inhibits carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I (CPT-I), the enzyme responsible for transporting fatty acyl-CoA into the mitochondrial matrix.
  • When CPT-I is inhibited, fatty acyl groups cannot enter the mitochondria, and thus, β-oxidation is blocked.

Explanation of other options:

Its formation from acetyl-CoA and bicarbonate by the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the main rate-limiting step in fatty acid synthesis (Option A): Although the formation of malonyl-CoA is indeed the rate-limiting step of fatty acid synthesis, this option does not explain the regulatory effect on fatty acid oxidation.

It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II (Option C): Malonyl-CoA specifically inhibits CPT-I, not CPT-II, which operates inside the mitochondria after the initial transport.

It prevents entry of fatty acyl groups into the matrix of the mitochondria because it is a potent inhibitor of carnitineacylcarnitine translocase (Option D): Malonyl-CoA does not inhibit carnitine acylcarnitine translocase; the key regulatory target is CPT-I.

Note:

  • The regulation of fatty acid oxidation by malonyl-CoA plays an important role in conditions such as fasting, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome, where energy substrate switching between carbohydrates and fats is crucial.
  • Dysregulation of this pathway can contribute to insulin resistance and other metabolic complications.
